title: Opinion: Folding bikes are terrible and you should buy one now
content:
Cyclist
Opinion: Folding bikes are terrible and you should buy one now 

There’s an old trope in photography that the best camera is the one you have with you. ‘Best’ might normally imply the most technologically advanced device with the most sophisticated sensor and cutting-edge optics, but none of that does you much good when something photo-worthy happens before your eyes and all you’ve got on you is your phone, while your ‘proper’ camera languishes at home.  

The point is you’re better off having a camera that is practical to take everywhere, rather than a bigger, heavier, more expensive one that might only come out for special occasions.  

I think there’s some truth in this for bicycles too, particularly in the realm of utility cycling. The ‘best’ bike is the one that fits into your life and works day to day, not the one that theoretically offers the most performance.  

I just spent a few days in my erstwhile home city of Edinburgh. This wasn’t a cycling holiday, but my wife and I wanted to relive our carefree youth and ride everywhere, because it’s by far the best way to get around and revisit old haunts.  

We intended to take bikes with us, but they had to be suitable for locking outdoors (ie, not too valuable) and, while we had a lot of stuff to transport, I was determined to fit the bikes inside the car. I once drove from Gloucestershire to Edinburgh with two bikes on the roof, and the fuel consumption penalty alone would have bought me a third bike.

It just so happens we have two folding bikes in the house right now, so the decision was an easy one. In the car they went, along with all our belongings.  

Folding bikes are pretty rubbish but also excellent 

Folders come in various flavours, from relatively capable large-wheel designs to those that focus on absolute portability, such as the classic Brompton. To varying degrees, they’re all fundamentally compromised, but that’s really not the point.  

For this trip I was riding a tired Dahon Vitesse D8 with 20-inch wheels, while my wife was on the quirky Big Fish Carnielli, a fascinatingly odd thing with 16-inch rims that I recently bought on eBay in never-used condition (look out for a future What We Ride piece on this – it’s really weird and I love it).  

Neither is the last word in sporting prowess, but the fact is they work. They’re thoroughly usable bikes that are eminently suited to whizzing across town.  

Edinburgh has some pretty gnarly cobbled streets as well as potholes you could live in, so the bikes weren’t always the most comfortable, but they coped well enough and let us do far more over the course of a few days than we’d have managed if we’d been relying on walking and taking the bus. 

This might all sound blindingly obvious but I’m keenly aware how easy it is to get hung up on cycling perfectionism.  

We bike tech nerds love to fret about the optimum setup for a given application, and this can lead to some needlessly black-and-white thinking, eg, ‘I must have a gravel bike that accepts 50mm tyres in case I suddenly need to go bikepacking in Chile’ or ‘this road bike is unrideable because its rims only measure 17mm internally and I won’t achieve ideal tyre volume from my 28s’.  

Never mind that these tiny details are completely irrelevant to the bigger picture, or that cyclists have made do with whatever bike they had since the dawn of the dandy horse.  

Folding bikes are objectively terrible when viewed solely through a performance lens. They’re often quite flexible since their frame design prioritises small size over rigidity, and their geometry typically leans towards the short, upright and twitchy. 

As an alternative to not cycling at all, however, they’re utterly fabulous, and that’s why you need to buy a folding bike right now. 

Folding bikes deals

Btwin 500: The budget option

  • RRP £379.99

The Btwin 500 is one of the cheapest folding bikes on the market from a reputable brand, but it checks a lot of boxes. The 20-inch wheels should give a more ‘big bike’ feel than some, while a 7-speed Shimano cassette offers a decent spread of gears.

Unusually, lights are included as standard and the total claimed weight of 12.9kg isn’t too shabby for a folder.

  • Buy now from Decathlon (£329.99)

Brompton C-Line: The quintessential folding bike

  • RRP from £1,250

Brompton really needs no introduction – it’s a genre-defining folding bike. While the basic A-Line is the most affordable option, the C-Line offers gearing options that are better suited to the majority of riders – a 2-speed drivetrain for the Urban model and a 6-speed for the Explore.

Bromptons use dinky 16in wheels and they fold down very small as a result. They’re comparatively expensive to buy but they hold their value exceptionally well compared to other bikes.

  • Read our Brompton C-Line first look and our P-Line and T-Line reviews
